messageBody:
Hiya, Chris

Thank you very much for your reply. I don't mind a bit that you've
selectively replied - any help is most welcome!

Get/Set tests are a pain, but I can indeed see that they're useful.
In fact, they turned up two of the issues that JUnit's found for me,
by exposing copy/paste errors. I haven't seen TestUtil before, but it
sounds interesting - I'll have a look at that. Have you used it
yourself?

The classes and methods (outside the get/sets) are indeed typically
quite large. Some of this is just because the DTO, Domain object and
Bean perforce contain all the properties and their get/sets, which
seems unavoidable to me.
But the Service classes and their methods are also large - For
example, a service update method would contain code to check the
values the user passes in, convert the incoming values to the proper
format, obtain the object they want to update, update that with each
value passed in, validate the updated object, apply any rules to it,
and return a message or a generated SOAPBean. These chunks of work
are typically extracted into separate methods, (at least, they are in
my code, so I can both reuse them and only test them once) but even
so, they're considerably larger than 10 lines...
Sounds like this is an area we should look into in more detail -
thank you!

We are indeed not doing TDD, basically because we don't know how! The
original aim was to work that way, but nobody could see how to do it.
Thank you for the link to the Squeak code - I will have a look at
that, and hopefully it'll give us some pointers.

Thank very much for your help,
Cheers
Tracey
